Articles.Content: Hi everyone, there's something I have always wondered about, and it came to mind as I was reading about tuesday's launch. So here it is: why did SpaceX change the arrangement of the nine Merlin engines of the F9 first stage from a 3x3 grid to the "octaweb"? Wikipedia just says it increases efficiency, but I was wondering how it does it. I'm sorry if this a stupid questions thanks!
You would have lower aerodynamic drag with the second arrangement.
Also in the first setup if you loose one of the corner engines it has an higher impact on your thrust vector then in the second arrangement.

I guess the exhaust of each nozzle does not interferes so much with their side nozzle, so the exhaust remains more collimated than the older way.. which increase efficiency.

EDIT: this is on spacex page

The Octaweb structure of the nine Merlin engines improves upon the former 3x3 engine arrangement. The Octaweb is a metal structure that supports eight engines surrounding a center engine at the base of the launch vehicle. This structure simplifies the design and assembly of the engine section, streamlining our manufacturing process.

Edited January 4, 2015 by AngelLestat
It might also be due to optimized plumbing.
Also if an engine is out there is less of a thrust imbalance through the center of mass.

Another factor to consider is the mass of the structure. I'd guess that having 8 engines equally spaced from the load bearing tank wall is lighter than having the eight engines zig-zaged (from the perspective of the tank wall).
